1.0    Executive Summary

COSL is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, COSL has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at these facilities.  One component of this system is a risk management program that is designed to manage the risks at COSL?s facilities.  Additionally, this RMP complies with all requirements of the California Accidental Release (CalARP), and the Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standards, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requirements.

The RMP at COSL consists of three elements:
1.    A hazard assessment to aid in understanding the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical accidental releases, and accidents that have occurred during the past five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule.
2.    A prevention program to assist in maintaining and safely operating any processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance.
3.    An emergency response program to help respond to an accidental release of regulated substances from the covered processes.
Information further describing these elements is provided in this Risk Management Plan.

Although the Risk Management Plan (RMP) at the COSL helps provide assurance that the WWTP and WTP facilities are maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of their overall safety program.  In fact, COSL has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing many levels of safeguards against the release of a hazardous substance, and injuries and damage resulting from a release of a hazardous substance.  COSL has a Safety Director who reviews relevant regulations and initiates safety committee walkthroughs.

COSL has limited its use of hazardous substances at its facilities.  Before using a hazardous substance at COSL, less hazardous alternatives are considered.  When a hazardous substance is used, COSL consid

ers the potential for this substance to adversely affect their employees, the public, and the environment, and takes steps to prevent such effects.

COSL works to prevent releases of hazardous substances that are employed at its facilities.  The City of Shasta Lake has limited the use of potentially hazardous substances that are regulated.  The WWTP and WTP facilities are very well maintained.  The facility and process equipment were designed, built, and are being operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  Industry and government standards were closely adhered to in the design, construction, and operation of the facilities and equipment.

COSL limits damage from a release, if such a release should occur.  COSL trains specific employees to respond to an accidental release, in order to reduce the consequence(s) of a release.  In addition, COSL works closely with the Shasta Lake Fire Protection District, which employs three Haz Mat trained firefighters, to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will be minimal, if a release should occur.

The safety program at COSL consists of a number of elements that conform to CalARP Program 3 requirements.  

1.1    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

COSL is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  COSL implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes at the facilities; and programs to manage the risks at facilities that store and use hazardous substances.

In the event of an accidental release, COSL and the Shasta Lake Fire Protection District will work to control and contain the spill in a manner that will be safe for the responders and the employees, and wil

l help prevent injury to the public and damage to the environment.  If an accidental release occurs, COSL will revise Sections 5 and 6 of this RMP to include information about the accident and the related incident investigation and provide it to EPA within six months.  Additionally, the expected date of completion of changes due to the accident investigation will be incorporated into the RMP and submitted to EPA within six months of the accident.

COSL provides response training to specific personnel, designates an emergency response coordinator to oversee response activities, and coordinates response efforts with the Shasta Lake Fire Protection District.  Three firefighters for the district, who have received Haz Mat training and are on the County Haz Mat Response team, are trained in the use of kits to repair chlorine and sulfur dioxide tank leaks.

To effectively implement these policies, the City of Shasta Lake established a management system headed by the City Manager along with the Waste Water Treatment Superintendent (with oversight for the WWTP) and the Water Treatment Superintendent (with oversight for the WTP) to oversee safety-related activities.  Both of these Superintendents report to the COSL City Manager.

1.2    COSL?s Regulated Substances Handled and Source Information

The City of Shasta Lake?s WWTP and WTP serve the City of Shasta Lake.  As part of the waste water treatment processes, chlorine gas is used and stored in sufficient quantities to be covered by the CalARP Program, Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management Standards, and U.S. EPA RMP requirements, as shown in Table 1.  As an additional part of the waste water treatment processes, sulfur dioxide gas is used and stored in sufficient quantities to be covered by the CalARP Program and Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management Standards,  as shown in Table 1.  Chlorine is employed and stored in sufficient quantities for the water treatment processes that it is covered by the CalARP Program, Cal/OSHA Process

Safety Management Standard, and and U.S. EPA RMP requirements, as shown in Table 1.

1.3    Off-Site Consequence Analysis (Appendix A)

An off-site consequence analysis was prepared to address worst-case and alternative scenarios for chlorine and sulfur dioxide releases from the City of Shasta Lake wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) and chlorine releases from COSL?s water treatment plant (WTP).  The complete off-site consequence analysis is presented in Appendix A.

1.4    Mitigation Measures

The City of Shasta Lake has implemented administrative controls and mitigation measures at both the wastewater treatment plant and the water treatment plant in order to minimize the potential of an off-site release or, in the event of a release, the quantity of the release.

Administrative controls in effect at the COSL facilities which were considered to mitigate the severity of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios include the City of Shasta Lake written policies and procedures for training of operators and maintenance personnel, written procedures for control of the inventory of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the facility, and policies regarding quality level of replacement materials and components for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems. Active mitigation measures include timely response of properly trained and equipped personnel following established emergency response procedures.  Other mitigation measures in place at the facilities include:

?    Placement of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems (including all cylinders stored) in dedicated rooms in enclosed buildings;
?    Leak detector sensors and interconnected audible/visual alarm systems for both the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems at the wastewater treatment plan

lfur dioxide for the COSL is presented in Appendix B.  The information available on the MSDSs for each hazardous substance typically includes:

 
?    toxicity information and permissible exposure limits
?    physical data (e.g., boiling point, melting point, flash point)
?    reactivity and corrosivity data
?    thermal and chemical stability data
?    hazards of mixing substances in the process

MSDSs for hazardous substances handled at each location are available in the main office of the WWTP and WTP so that the operators have ready accessibility to this information.  In addition, MSDSs are provided to the emergency response team and the fire department for use in developing emergency response planning.

1.5.1    Process Hazard Analysis (Appendix C)

A process hazard analysis (PHAs) was performed of the covered COSL processes, to identify potential hazards and produce recommendations that may promote safer operation of these processes.  The PHA is updated at least every 5 years or when significant changes occur.  A team composed of personnel with engineering process operating experience, and a leader with process hazard analyses experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of each process.  PHA What-If Questions and a Hazard Review Checklist were used to perform the analysis (see Appendix C).  Responsibility to resolve the recommendations is assigned to unit personnel and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the processes are implemented.  The PHA team incorporated information from the site inspection into the responses on the PHA What-If Questions and the Hazard Review Checklist in Appendix C.  

1.5.2    Operating Procedures (Appendix D)

COSL operators and superintendents work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to be taken during both normal operations and proces

s upsets.

COSL personnel develop and maintain operating procedures that cover all phases of operations, including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown.  This information is found in the Operations and Maintenance (O & M) Manuals located in the WWTP and WTP offices.  

Appendix D includes certain other relevant information:

?    WTP site plan
?    block flow diagrams for WWTP and WTP
?    overall site plan for WWTP
?    chemical/electrical building plan for WWTP

When important information is not available from the design documents, it should be developed through special projects or, in the case of operating parameters, during the process hazards analyses.  Many of the operating parameters are included in the operating procedures to help with the safe operation of the process.  These documents are used to train employees, to perform process hazards analyses, and to help maintain the equipment.
 
1.5.3    Training (Appendix E)

The COSL has permits to operate the facilities, and operators at the WWTP and WTP are state-certified for working with or around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes, so they can safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  The training programs for the operators cover the properties of the substances and the hazards of those substances.  The training programs also include orientation to the layout and operation of the chlorine process for that facility and, for WWTP operators, the sulfur dioxide process.  As of the publication date of this RMP, all the current full-time WWTP operators have had at least three semesters of relevant education in the water technology program at Shasta College for wastewater treatment operation.  Operators of the WTP are required to pass the state certification exam and complete a specified number of continuing education units related to water treatment plant operations on an ong

oing basis.  In addition, safety tailgate meetings are held at the WWTP and WTP approximately every two to four weeks.

The COSL conducts training for WWTP and WTP operators covering the use of full-face supplied air respirators, personal protective equipment (PPE); chlorine safety; safe cylinder changing procedures; and understanding MSDS sheets.  Training is documented and kept on file at the WWTP and WTP, as applicable.

1.5.4    Mechanical Integrity (Appendix F) 

The City of Shasta Lake carries out a mechanical integrity program for chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes at COSL?s wastewater treatment plant and the water treatment plant.  The purpose of the mechanical integrity program is to ensure that all vessels, piping, instrumentation, and other components essential to the containment of this material are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of accidental release.  The elements of COSL?s mechanical integrity program for chlorine and sulfur dioxide include:

?    Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation, 
?    Maintenance procedures, 
?    Training of maintenance personnel, 
?    Defined inspection and test procedures and frequencies, 
?    Establishment of criteria for acceptable test results, 
?    Documentation of test and inspection results, and 
?    A quality assurance program to help ensure that equipment is designed, fabricated, and installed properly.

Details of the mechanical integrity program are described in Appendix F.

1.5.5    Pre-startup Review (Appendix G)

The City of Shasta Lake performs a Pre-Startup Safety Review of any new or modified process prior to the introduction of chlorine or sulfur dioxide, to ensure that the system will operate safely.  This review confirms:

?    Construction is in accordance with specifications;
?    Appropriate testing and inspections have been performed;
?    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; 
?    Safety Review recommendations have been

addressed and actions required for startup have been completed; and
?    Operating procedures are in place and training of personnel has been completed.

Details of the Pre-Startup Safety Review process, including checklists to be used during the review, are presented in Appendix G.

1.5.6    Management of Change (Appendix H)

The COSL Management of Change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process, to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  Process changes that are determined to be a replacement in kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) are allowed without implementing the full Management of Change program.

All major changes to processes must be confirmed through the Management of Change program, in order to ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

1.5.7    Compliance Audit (Appendix I)

COSL conducted a Compliance Audit on June 20, 2002.  That audit covered the processes to determine whether the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the operations.  COSL assembled an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the RMP rule and in the processes, and this team evaluated whether the prevention program satisfies the requirement of the RMP rule, and whether it is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the processes.  

1.5.8    Incident Investigation (Appendix J)

COSL will investigate all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment, so that similar accidents can be prevented.  COSL provides training to employees in order to identify and report any incident requiring investigation. An investigation team will be assembled, and the investigation will be initiated within 48

hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation will be documented, recommendations will be addressed, and appropriate process enhancements will be implemented.

1.5.9    Employee Participation Program (Appendix K)

COSL has developed an employee participation program to help ensure that the safety concerns of the workers are properly addressed.  COSL encourages active participation of its personnel in the prevention program.  Specific employees that work with or around the chlorine gas process are consulted and informed about the RMP prevention program, including PHAs and standard operating procedures.

1.5.10    Hot Work Permits (Appendix L)

COSL established a Hot Work Permit Program to monitor and control spark- or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions in covered processes at the WWTP and WTP facilities.  COSL will use a Hot Work Permit Form to comply with Cal/OSHA requirements.  Personnel who perform hot work within the chlorine gas process or sulfur dioxide process areas are required to fill out the Hot Work Permit Form.  The supervisors review the completed forms before work can commence.  Training in the use of the Hot Work Permit Form is included in the COSL safe work practices orientation.

1.5.11    Contractor Safety (Appendix M)

COSL established a program to help ensure that contractor activities at the WWTP and WTP facilities are performed in a safe manner.  COSL only utilizes contractors who can safely perform the desired job tasks.  COSL explains to the contract supervisors the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, safe work practices, and proper emergency response procedures.  COSL personnel inspect contractor work activities when working near the WWTP and WTP chlorine process areas to help ensure that safe work practices are followed.

1.6    Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

At the WWTP, disinfection is accomplished through treated wastewater being injected with chlorine gas.  Following c

hlorination, sulfur dioxide is induced into the chlorinated wastewater for dechlorination, and the effluent is discharged to Churn Creek.  

In addition to the required prevention program elements, COSL has implemented safety features specific to the chlorine gas processes used at both the WWTP and WTP facilities.  These features are further described in the following paragraphs.

At both facilities, chlorine is stored in DOT-approved cylinders, which are supplied by Sierra Chemical (1-800-777-8965).  Sulfur dioxide at the WWTP is also stored in DOT-approved cylinders, which are supplied by Sierra Chemical.  COSL employs certified chlorine process control companies and engineers to design, maintain, and service COSL?s chlorine control systems and related equipment, as well as their sulfur dioxide control systems and related equipment.  The systems are maintained every 2 years.  Maintenance was performed on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems in June 2004.  This preventative maintenance program is ongoing.  Repairs are completed and/or new equipment is installed, if existing equipment is found to be defective or worn.  In February 2004, the manufacturer?s authorized service representative replaced circuit board in the controller for the sulfonator in the sulfur dioxide system.  Selected spare parts are provided in case COSL?s employees are required to perform specific repairs.

There are two chlorine/sulfur dioxide leak detector sensors located near the floor in the chlorine and sulfur dioxide rooms, respectively, that alarm at the operator?s panel.  If these alarms are not acknowledged within three minutes, the on-call WWTP operators are autodialed in sequence at their contact number outside of work and notified.  The on-call operators are within a 25 to 45-minute response time of the WWTP. As an additional precaution, there are on-site automatic audible and visible alarms (red lights outside both entry doors that alert employees and visitors to evacuate the pre

mises).  These alarms are also connected to the automated system.  All alarms have uninterrupted power supplies (battery back up system).  If the power is off for short time, then the auxiliary emergency generator is put on-line to provide power for critical equipment at the WWTP.  At the WTP, there is currently no auxiliary emergency generator but is being discussed for installation in the future.  Automatic shut-off valves are located on the downstream side of the flexible pigtail connection at each cylinder that will shut down the systems upon sensing low pressure in the piping downstream from this valve.  If a release occurs downstream of the vacuum switchover valve (vacuum loss), the valve will close and only the quantity in the piping will be released.  Air-supplied respirators are located outside the Chemical/Electrical Building.

Six one-ton chlorine cylinders and two one-ton sulfur dioxide cylinders at the WWTP are strapped onto the saddle supports that are bolted to the slab (per design drawings).  When transporting a one-ton cylinder from the delivery truck to the Chemical/Electrical Building which houses the chlorine and sulfur dioxide cylinders (using the monorail hoist system), only trained employees complete the cylinder transfer process, and they adhere to strict guidelines.

The WTP facility has two one-ton chlorine cylinders that are strapped onto the saddle supports that are bolted to the slab (per design drawings).  Flexible pigtail connections are used and the piping is adequately supported.  The chlorine use and storage room has one chlorine leak detector sensor, an alarm system (with a backup notification system), a ventilation system, and a light that will energize to warn the persons entering the room, if a leak has been detected.  There are no automatic shut-off valves located at the cylinders or on the flexible pigtail connectors.  Air-supplied respirators are located in the breezeway outside the building.  

In both facilities, the piping

systems and supports appear to be up to the required standards, and pipe supports are securely mounted to solid structures.  The cylinders are located within areas that will secure them from large objects, which could fall and damage the cylinders or supply system.  Equipment inspections are regularly conducted and recorded by operational staff. 

When transporting a one-ton cylinder from the storage location to the on-line cylinder area, the valve cover will remain in place, the tank will be loaded and unloaded utilizing the proper equipment, and the cylinder will be set into a saddle support.  Only trained employees will complete the cylinder transfer process, and will adhere to strict guidelines when completing this process.

1.7    Five-Year Accident History (Section 5.0)

COSL has reported no accidents, personal injuries, or property damage in the last five years, with regard to a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas.  If an incident occurs, an investigation team will conduct an investigation following the incident investigation protocol.  The team will suggest improvements to the process and, if appropriate, improvements will be made.  Additionally, a report will be completed and will be kept on file.

1.8    Emergency Response Program (Section 8.0)

COSL has established a written emergency response program to ensure a safe response to an accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for: 

?    Fires 
?    Medical Emergencies
?    Earthquakes
?    Emergency Spills

The Shasta Lake Fire Protection District employs three firefighters, who have received Haz Mat training and are on the Shasta County Haz Mat Response team.  These specialists are trained in the use of kits to repair chlorine and sulfur dioxide tank leaks.  All affected COSL personnel and the Shasta Lake Fire Protection District have been notified of the emergency response plan and procedures, which serves as the local emergency response team.

1.9    Planne

d Changes to Improve Safety

The City of Shasta Lake constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated processes, through both the incident investigation program and the practice of encouraging safety suggestions for improvement from the workers.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide process systems at the WWTP and the chlorine process at the WTP facilities are inspected daily by the COSL operators.  The preventative maintenance program helps ensure that the equipment and processes are operating in a safe and efficient manner.
